author: By Ben H. Winters
title: All the World Needs Is a Glowing Blue Supermetal From Space
description: Benjamin Percy’s novel “The Ninth Metal” imagines a cutthroat race for meteor deposits with extraordinary properties.
content: THE NINTH METALBy Benjamin Percy
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: With Her Candor, Osaka Adds to Conversation About Mental Health
description: Making herself vulnerable, she joins other noteworthy athletes in pushing the once-taboo subject into the open.
content: Naomi Osaka’s withdrawal this week from the French Open stunned tennis. But her decision was also a potent example of a movement among elite athletes to challenge the age-old notion that they are, and must be, as peerless in mind as they are in body, untroubled by the scourge of mental illness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Bo Burnham’s ‘Inside’: A Comedy Special and an Inspired Experiment
description: Using cinematic tools other comics overlook, the star (who is also the director, editor and cameraman) trains a glaring spotlight on internet life mid-pandemic.
content: One of the most encouraging developments in comedy over the past decade has been the growing directorial ambition of stand-up specials. It’s folly to duplicate the feel of a live set, so why not fully adjust to the screen and try to make something as visually ambitious as a feature?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: Lost Lead Recalls Mavericks’ Crash of ’06
description: Fifteen years ago, the Mavericks lost the N.B.A. finals after winning the first two games of the series. Now they have blown a 2-0 series lead over the Clippers.
content: DALLAS — The Dallas Mavericks are one of only four teams to win the first two games in the N.B.A. finals and still lose the series. It was always assumed thereafter that, for this franchise and its fans, no playoff collapse could inflict as much pain as Dallas’s disintegration against the Miami Heat in 2006.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: As Biden Vows to ‘Fight Like Heck,’ Voting Overhaul Falters in Congress
description: Opposition from Republicans and some of their own senators has left Democrats struggling to determine whether they should try to nix the filibuster to save a top priority.
content: WASHINGTON — In the national struggle over voting rights, Democrats have rested their hopes for turning back a wave of new restrictions in Republican-led states and expanding ballot access on their narrow majorities in Congress. Failure, they have repeatedly insisted, “is not an option.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: A new kind of pandemic grief.
content: As new infections plummet, many newly vaccinated Americans are leaving their masks behind, planning summer travel and joyously reuniting with family and friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Supreme Court’s Big Month
description: Four big cases and three questions.
content: June is peak season for Supreme Court decisions. It is the final month of the court’s annual term, and the justices tend to save their biggest decisions for the term’s end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: ‘For My People’: A Transgender Woman Pursues an Olympic Dream
description: CeCe Telfer, the first openly transgender woman to win an N.C.A.A. title, is aiming to qualify for the U.S. Olympic trials in the 400-meter hurdles. Her biggest obstacle, for now, is a lack of training facilities.
content: SWANZEY, N.H. — During a drive on a steep, winding road in this small town, it would not be surprising these days to see an elite hurdler jump into the bushes to avoid being hit by a car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Murphy
title: How to Rearrange Your Post-Pandemic ‘Friendscape’
description: Re-entry offers an opportunity to choose which relationships we wish to resurrect and which are better left dormant.
content: Any traumatic experience — like a breakup, health scare, death in the family or financial crisis — has a way of destabilizing social networks. We instinctively gravitate toward those who provide comfort and support and reflexively withdraw from those who drain and drag us down.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New & Noteworthy, From Hidden Treasure to a Relic of Slavery
description: A selection of recent titles of interest; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
content: FROM THE ASHES: My Story of Being Indigenous, Homeless, and Finding My Way, by Jesse Thistle. (Atria, paper, $17.) Raised by foster families and tough but loving grandparents, Thistle — a Métis-Cree from western Canada — overcame addiction and hardship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser and Jade-Snow Joachim
title: Alaska, Vaccine Passport, Naomi Osaka: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy S. Greenberg
title: Pulling Back the Curtain on the Lincolns’ Marriage
description: In “An American Marriage,” Michael Burlingame portrays Abraham and Mary as being constantly at each other’s throat.
content: AN AMERICAN MARRIAGEThe Untold Story of Abraham Lincoln and Mary ToddBy Michael Burlingame
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Star Chef From Peru to Head Public Hotel Restaurants
description: A fish and chips operation from Ed Szymanski, formerly of Cherry Point; a plant-based chain’s first New York location; and more restaurant news.
content: The global hotelier Ian Schrager has completely made over the restaurants, entry and garden at his Public hotel on the Lower East Side, which was closed as a result of the pandemic. He opened it just four years ago with Jean-Georges Vongerichten as its marquee chef. Now he is introducing a Peruvian star, Diego Muñoz, to New York to create the food at Popular, the new signature restaurant on the property, and also to oversee the adjacent Cantina & Pisco Bar. Among Mr. Muñoz’s credits are the kitchens of Astrid y Gastón in Lima, Peru, and the Edition in Bodrum, Turkey, another Schrager hotel, as well as other projects in Peru. Working alongside Mr. Muñoz will be John Fraser, another chef in Mr. Schrager’s lineup, who will attend mainly to the restaurant management side of things. Mr. Schrager noted that this collaboration of two top chefs was something he has never done. Mr. Fraser will also curate the prepared grab-and-go items, including some by Mr. Muñoz, at Louis, a ground-floor market and coffee bar. The Cantina & Pisco Bar is a pair of marble counters, one with fresh fish on display for ceviche made to order, the other for cocktails starring pisco. There is also table seating. Popular has indoor and outdoor seating for a menu highlighting the multicultural traditions — African, Chinese, Incan, Italian, Japanese and Spanish  — that shape Peruvian cuisine in many seafood preparations, and also in dishes like papa a la Huancaína, a classic Peruvian potato dish; filet mignon saltado, a dressier version of the staple; salmon tiradito for the Japanese influence; and wood-smoked seafood paella, plus the inevitable burger. There are three wood ovens. On the Cantina & Pisco Bar menu will be razor clams, and hearts of palm with avocado. Louis will offer a ceviche bowl, Peruvian-style sandwiches and also a loaded Chrystie Street kosher hot dog; Mr. Muñoz will be coming up with cocktails at Cantina and Popular, many based on pisco, the grape spirit of Peru. Peruvian and South American selections dominate the wine list. (Opens June 12; reservations accepted from June 5.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: The ‘Mean Greens’ Are Forcing Exxon to Clean Up Its Act
description: Diversifying beyond oil and gas will benefit everyone.
content: Since the 1990s, the wisest oil-producing countries and companies have regularly reminded themselves of the oil patch adage that the Stone Age did not end because we ran out of stones; it ended because we invented bronze tools. When we did, stone tools became worthless — even though there were still plenty on the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Add ‘Climate Hazards’ to Your Home-Buyer’s Checklist
description: Maps and other data are now available to help buyers analyze the risks of fires, floods and other disasters when searching for a new house.
content: As global temperatures increase and sea levels rise, home shoppers are looking at more than just location, price and the number of bedrooms when exploring properties. They are also wondering about the risk of natural disaster, and what that risk might mean for a home’s value over time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Dissecting the California Recall
description: Tuesday: We explore the historical, technical, logistical and financial aspects of the attempt to recall Gov. Gavin Newsom.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Finney Boylan
title: In 17 Years, I Will Still Know My Own Heart
description: The cycles of queer progress.
content: I was lying in my bed listening to the cicadas sing. The “Loreleis of the insect world,” as The New York Times called them that month, had emerged to “drum their compelling love song to herald yet another cycle of their amazing and mysterious 17-year life span.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Burning of Black Tulsa
description: A century after a race massacre that leveled businesses and homes, and killed hundreds, what would justice look like?
content: This episode includes disturbing language including racial slurs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Master the Art of the Toast
description: A new book gives readers a look at how people raise their glasses around the world.
content: Say you’re invited to a wedding where the groom is from Indonesia or the bride is Romanian, and you’d like to toast them in their native languages. A new book, “Cheers! Around the World in 80 Toasts,” will tell you that “Bersulang!” or “Noroc!” are what you need to say as you raise your glass. This global lexicon, written with a light touch, is a scholarly treatise on toasts in scores of languages and takes a deep dive into linguistics, history and traditions. The author, a writer and teacher, is proficient in five languages. He has organized the book by region, with the countries in each listed in alphabetical order for easy reference. You’ll discover what to say, what libation should fill the glass and how it all came about. Read it with a clear head; there’s much to learn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Australia’s softball players are among the first Olympic athletes to arrive in Japan.
description: The team will be confined to one floor of a hotel as it prepares for the Tokyo Games, which are scheduled to begin July 23 despite a coronavirus outbreak and growing public opposition.
content: Players from Australia’s national women’s softball team arrived in Japan on Tuesday ahead of the Tokyo Olympics, a show of confidence in a beleaguered event that is struggling against a coronavirus outbreak and growing public opposition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: Will the Excelsior Pass, New York’s Vaccine Passport, Catch On?
description: More than one million Excelsior passes have been downloaded since they were introduced, but officials are hoping they will be adopted more widely.
content: On the Upper East Side in Manhattan, a well-heeled crowd flashed it to get into a socially distanced dance performance at the Park Avenue Armory. In Chelsea, people showed it to attend a John Mulaney stand-up set at City Winery. And in Troy, N.Y., patrons are using it to enter an intimate, speakeasy-style bar that only admits vaccinated guests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elon Green
title: The Young Activist and the Atlanta Bar That Shaped Queer History
description: In “A Night at the Sweet Gum Head,” Martin Padgett follows the L.G.B.T.Q. activist Bill Smith and the drag queen John Greenwell to chronicle 1970s queer history.
content: A NIGHT AT THE SWEET GUM HEADDrag, Drugs, Disco, and Atlanta’s Gay RevolutionBy Martin Padgett
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aanya Wipulasena and Mujib Mashal
title: Sri Lanka, Facing ‘Worst’ Marine Disaster, Investigates Cargo Ship Fire
description: A fire has raged on a cargo ship off the coast of Sri Lanka for 12 days, sending toxic chemicals and tons of plastic into the country’s waters and polluting its beaches.
content: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — The authorities in Sri Lanka have opened a criminal investigation into the crew of a cargo ship laden with toxic chemicals that has been burning off the island nation’s coast for 12 days, spilling debris into the ocean and polluting the country’s beaches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman and Niraj Chokshi
title: How the World Ran Out of Everything
description: Global shortages of many goods reflect the disruption of the pandemic combined with decades of companies limiting their inventories.
content: In the story of how the modern world was constructed, Toyota stands out as the mastermind of a monumental advance in industrial efficiency. The Japanese automaker pioneered so-called Just In Time manufacturing, in which parts are delivered to factories right as they are required, minimizing the need to stockpile them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: A Crossroads for N.Y.C. Pride
description: The decision to ban police officers from marching as a group  has spurred a wave of questions over the future of  the celebration.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: A tabloid publisher will pay a $187,500 F.E.C. penalty for its Trump hush-money payment.
description: But Donald Trump faces no further investigation or penalties related to the 2016 payment to a former Playboy model by the publisher of The National Enquirer.
content: The tabloid publishing company that paid $150,000 to a former Playboy model in 2016 to suppress her account of an alleged affair with Donald J. Trump, then a presidential candidate, has agreed to pay $187,500 to the Federal Election Commission to settle accusations that the company violated campaign finance law in making the payment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: Have Three Children? No Way, Many Chinese Say.
description: Intense workplace competition, inadequate child care and widespread job discrimination against pregnant women have made childbearing an unappealing prospect for many.
content: After China said it would allow couples to have three children, the state news media trumpeted the move as a major change that would help stimulate growth. But across much of the country, the announcement was met with indignation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: French Heir Gives Pissarro Stolen by the Nazis to a U.S. University
description: The painting, long the subject of an ownership dispute, will be given to the University of Oklahoma with plans for title to be transferred later, likely to a French institution.
content: A Jewish family whose relatives had their artworks looted by the Nazis said on Tuesday they were giving up their claim to a Pissarro painting and transferring ownership to the University of Oklahoma, where it had been on display until 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: On Vaccine Mandates, the G.O.P. Isn’t on Its Own Anymore
description: Support for vaccine passports has once again fallen along partisan lines — but it isn’t as divisive as other pandemic precautions.
content: Businesses are now allowed to require their employees to be vaccinated, so long as they abide by federal regulations for employer mandates, according to guidelines released late last week by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Michael Flynn suggested at a QAnon-affiliated event that a coup should happen in the U.S.
description: At the same event, Representative Louie Gohmert, a Republican from Texas, repeated a widely debunked claim that right-wing extremists were not solely responsible for the Capitol riot.
content: Michael T. Flynn, a former national security adviser, suggested that a military coup was needed in the United States during a Memorial Day weekend conference organized by adherents of the QAnon conspiracy theory, drawing criticism from political scientists, veterans, Democrats and a handful of prominent Republicans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aliza Weinberger
title: Nicola Yoon’s New Book Is a Romance About a Teenager Who Doesn’t Believe in Love
description: In Nicola Yoon’s book “Instructions for Dancing,” a teenager who doesn’t believe in love rediscovers romance through dance classes.
content: INSTRUCTIONS FOR DANCINGBy Nicola Yoon
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Lesbians in Ballet: ‘Has Anyone Like Me Ever Walked These Halls?’
description: Ballet’s strict gender norms put pressure on women to conform. But dancers who don’t are finding they’re not alone.
content: As a teenage ballet student in the 1990s, Katy Pyle had no interest in dating: not boys, not girls, not anyone. A serious love interest — all consuming, really — was already in the picture: ballet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Feel Small
description: Stare out at the ocean. Look up at the stars. Realize you are part of something much bigger and more important than you.
content: “You don’t need to go to the Grand Canyon,” says Paul K. Piff, an associate professor of psychological science who runs the Morality, Emotion and Social Hierarchy Lab at the University of California, Irvine. Piff studies what he calls the small self — the feeling of being part of something much bigger and more important than you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel and Anna Watts
title: Barbecues, Birthdays and Tangos: New York Parks Are Bustling Again
description: While Memorial Day is the unofficial start to summer in the city, New Yorkers have already been filling the city’s green spaces, celebrating the joy of being together.
content: The first signs of summer in New York City are often subtle: hydrants dribbling water down the block; Mr. Softee trucks patrolling the neighborhood; the air on trash night smelling riper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: The Discovery chief David Zaslav greets his WarnerMedia troops.
description: A company name is unveiled — Warner Bros. Discovery . And a tagline to go with it: “The stuff that dreams are made of.”
content: The new media company that would combine WarnerMedia and Discovery has a name: Warner Bros. Discovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Moderna applies for full F.D.A. approval for its Covid vaccine.
description: The company’s application follows the move by Pfizer and BioNTech to seek full approval last month. The vaccines already have emergency use authorization in the United States.
content: Moderna on Tuesday became the latest pharmaceutical company to apply to the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for full approval for its Covid-19 vaccine for use in people 18 and older. F.D.A. approval would allow the company to market the shot directly to consumers, and could also help raise public confidence in the vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Want to Win $5 Million? Get Vaccinated, New Mexico Says.
description: As states scramble to persuade people to get coronavirus vaccines, New Mexico announces one of the biggest cash awards as an incentive.
content: When the book is written about how states across the country tried to persuade people to get coronavirus vaccines, it will not accuse New Mexico of being subtle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Maclaughlin
title: A Book About Absorbing What We Love Until It Transforms Us
description: “A Ghost in the Throat,” by Doireann Ni Ghriofa, is part memoir, part literary investigation of a 250-year-old poem.
content: A GHOST IN THE THROAT By Doireann Ni Ghriofa
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Bach’s Cello Suites, Now on Violin, With a Folksy Feel
description: With an ear for dance and a new five-string violin, Johnny Gandelsman set out to transform a towering classic.
content: Bargemusic was rocking last Friday evening as rain fell heavily outside, casting the view of Lower Manhattan in gray.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: ‘You Feel Goose Bumps’: The Push to Preserve Where Wilde Was Jailed for Being Gay
description: Activists are trying to preserve the prison he was sent to after his conviction for “indecency,” saying his life is an important part of Britain’s history.
content: READING, England — The metal stairway creaks and groans underfoot on the way to cell C. 3.3, a bare oblong room of painted brick behind a large and forbidding prison door.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian Lucas
title: How America Remembers— and Distorts — Its Slavery Past
description: In “How the Word Is Passed,” the poet and journalist Clint Smith visits nine places to assess how we are reckoning with our racial history and its legacy.
content: HOW THE WORD IS PASSEDA Reckoning With the History of Slavery Across AmericaBy Clint Smith
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Inverness Is Closer Than You Think
description: Cowgirl Creamery’s Inverness is buttery, with a subtle tang. And it’s now available nationwide.
content: Tiny delicacies are often most worth treasuring. Cowgirl Creamery — an organic cheese company in Petaluma, Calif., in Sonoma County — has been making a lovely cheese called Inverness. Not only is the cheese itself a mini, a cylinder about the size of a cannele pastry and about two ounces, it’s made in limited quantities, the company’s smallest production. It’s now available nationally. A pale, textured rind encloses its creamy, slightly chalky interior, and its mildly buttery flavor has a tangy underpinning. Give it a couple of hours at room temperature for the texture to soften and the complexity to bloom. It’s named for an area near San Francisco, not far from the company’s tasting room in Point Reyes. Serve it with a breezy Sonoma Coast chardonnay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: W.H.O. approval for a second Chinese vaccine.
content: The World Health Organization cleared a Covid-19 vaccine made by the Chinese drugmaker Sinovac Biotech for emergency use. The clearance means that the vaccine could be distributed as part of Covax, the global effort to share shots with hard-hit, undersupplied nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: As M.L.B. Honors Lou Gehrig, It Shines a Spotlight on A.L.S.
description: Gwen Petersen, who has Lou Gehrig’s disease, is one of the many advocates who view the league’s new event as a chance to raise awareness and funding.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — On the day Lou Gehrig stood at a microphone at Yankee Stadium and, with a few simple words, inspired a nation with his courage and optimism, the disease that was slowly destroying his body had not yet done its worst.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Obama Explains How America Went From ‘Yes We Can’ to ‘MAGA’
description: The former president also discusses Joe Biden, aliens and three of his favorite books.
content: “My entire politics is premised on the fact that we are these tiny organisms on this little speck floating in the middle of space,” Barack Obama told me, sitting in his office in Washington, D.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir and Steve Wembi
title: Covid has killed over 5 percent of lawmakers in Congo’s Parliament.
description: The rising toll comes as the country struggles with a difficult vaccine rollout, the presence of other deadly diseases and eruption of one of the world’s most dangerous volcanoes.
content: The coronavirus has now claimed the lives of 32 lawmakers in the Democratic Republic of Congo — more than 5 percent of its Parliament — the authorities say, a reflection of how the coronavirus continues to pose a widespread threat in some parts of the world even as others increasingly resume pre-pandemic behavior.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: Serena Williams Wins in the First Round at the French Open
description: Playing in a night session in Paris, Williams defeated Irina-Camelia Begu in straight sets in a brisk match that moved her along to the second round, again.
content: PARIS — In a new time slot, Serena Williams kept her return engagement with the second round of a Grand Slam once more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Why Could Boris Johnson Marry in a Catholic Church?
description: The British prime minister was married twice before, but the church didn’t recognize those unions because they were not Catholic.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s marriage to his fiancée, Carrie Symonds, on Saturday caught even his closest advisers off guard. Yet, perhaps the most surprising thing about the stealth ceremony was how by-the-book it was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophia June
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $3.75 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: A New Champion of Short Ribs in Koreatown
description: Yoon Haeundae Galbi traces its method for making the cut tender back to a restaurant founded in Busan in 1964.
content: There is something deeply admirable about a menu that knows how to quit when it is ahead. When the choices have been edited to the essentials, you don’t need to ask the server, “What’s good here?” and the servers don’t need to lie and say, “Everything.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Tokyo Olympics: Athletes to Watch This Summer
description: Looking for some names to root for? Start here.
content: No list of Olympic athletes could encompass all the stories of human achievement on display at the Summer Games. But if you’re looking for some names to root for (or against) in Tokyo, here are a few to start with. (Note that some still need to qualify to compete this year.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard J. Tofel
title: Drew Pearson, the Muckraking Journalist With the Bully Pulpit
description: Donald A. Ritchie’s “The Columnist” describes the 37-year career of a journalist who was, in his time, one of the most powerful men in Washington.
content: THE COLUMNISTLeaks, Lies, and Libel in Drew Pearson’s WashingtonBy Donald A. Ritchie
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell, Nicole Perlroth and Noam Scheiber
title: Ransomware Disrupts Meat Plants in Latest Attack on Critical U.S. Business
description: All of JBS’s beef plants in the U.S. were shuttered on Tuesday, and many of its pork and poultry plants were affected, according to a union and Facebook posts meant for employees.
content: A cyberattack on the world’s largest meat processor forced the shutdown of nine beef plants in the United States on Tuesday, according to union officials, and disrupted production at poultry and pork plants. The attack could upset the nation’s meat markets and raises new questions about the vulnerability of critical American businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: Amid Historic Drought, a New Water War in the West
description: A drought crisis has erupted in the Klamath Basin along the California-Oregon border, with fish dying en masse and farmers infuriated that they have been cut off from their main water source.
content: KLAMATH FALLS, Ore. — Through the marshlands along the Oregon-California border, the federal government a century ago carved a whole new landscape, draining lakes and channeling rivers to build a farming economy that now supplies alfalfa for dairy cows and potatoes for Frito-Lay chips.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Krispy Kreme reveals its plans for an initial public offering trading as DNUT.
description: The company’s sales grew 17 percent to $1.1 billion its last fiscal year. Losses nearly doubled, to $60 million.
content: Krispy Kreme, the doughnut giant owned by the European investment firm JAB Holding, is planning to sell stock to the public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley, Isabel Kershner and Adam Rasgon
title: As Israelis Await Netanyahu’s Fate, Palestinians Seize a Moment of Unity
description: Seeing little hope for major change from a new Israeli government, Palestinians are focused on an internal generational shift toward a campaign for rights and justice.
content: JERUSALEM — When Israelis opened their newspapers and news websites on Tuesday, they encountered a barrage of reports and commentary about the possible downfall of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, the country’s longest-serving leader.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Elsie Chen
title: China Wants More Babies. Some Men Choose Vasectomies.
description: As the Chinese government tries to increase the country’s falling birthrate, some millennials are striving for a lifestyle commonly known as “Double Income, No Kids.”
content: Huang Yulong never wanted a baby. As a child, he resented his parents, who left him in the care of relatives while they worked in faraway factories, visiting roughly once a year. He never felt a need to reproduce or pass on the family name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Pope Widens Church Law to Cover Sexual Abuse of Adults by Priests and Laity
description: The new rules explicitly criminalize the sexual exploitation of adults by priests who abuse their authority, and the changes also apply to laypeople with power in the church.
content: ROME — Pope Francis has broadened the Roman Catholic Church’s definition of sexual abuse by revising its penal code to explicitly acknowledge that adults, and not only children, can be victimized by priests and powerful laypeople who abuse their offices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Florida’s Democratic agricultural commissioner, Nikki Fried, announces her bid for governor.
description: Ms. Fried is hoping to emerge as the Democratic Party’s strongest candidate to unseat Gov. Ron DeSantis, a popular Republican.
content: MIAMI — Nikki Fried, Florida’s agriculture commissioner, declared her candidacy for governor on Tuesday, casting herself as the Democratic Party’s best option to defeat Ron DeSantis, the popular Republican incumbent, given her role as the only statewide elected Democrat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Biden unveiled a plan to help Black businesses and homeowners during his visit to Tulsa.
description: The initiative includes a pledge to boost federal contracts to minority-owned businesses and a rollback of Trump-era actions that hamstrung fair housing laws.
content: President Biden on Tuesday announced several initiatives to reduce racial disparities, including a pledge to boost federal contracts to minority-owned businesses by 50 percent and a rollback of two Trump-era actions that have hamstrung fair housing laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hahna Yoon
title: In Korea, You Don’t Have to Explain TikTok to Your Grandma
description: Through videos on YouTube and TikTok that feature their lives, fashions and routines, many Koreans are challenging the idea that such media are a young person’s game.
content: SEOUL — In 2017 Kim Yura shot a video during a vacation she took to the Australian city of Cairns and later posted it on a YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Illinois Lawmakers Bar Police From Using Deception When Interrogating Minors
description: A bill that passed the General Assembly with bipartisan support on Sunday would make Illinois the first state to prohibit officers from lying when interrogating those under 18.
content: Illinois would become the first state to bar the police from using deceptive tactics when interrogating young people under legislation that passed the General Assembly with near-unanimous support from Republicans and Democrats on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: The Human Toll of Bearing Witness
description: Smartphone videos are tools for bearing witness and holding the powerful to account. But they come at a cost.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Weed
title: Dream Trips Without the Crowds? That’s the Hope, Anyway.
description: Tour companies are reporting a resurgence in interest for trips to bucket-list destinations, where travelers can still see the sites without being jostled.
content: It was the chance to visit a once-in-a-lifetime destination in a once-in-a-lifetime way: practically alone. Visiting the sites of ancient Egypt had long been on the bucket list of Alexander Pancoe, 34, and Nina Laski, 27, of Chicago. Last winter, when they learned the country was open to tourists despite the pandemic, they planned a trip to Luxor and the Valley of The Kings. Places like the Temple of Karnak, which would be packed in the high season, “we had all to ourselves,” Mr. Pancoe said, and were even more stunning than they expected. “There is no photo or movie that does justice to the place,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Jennings
title: Breaking Out of Prison With a Ouija Board and Some Clever Tricks
description: “The Confidence Men,” by Margalit Fox, recounts the elaborate true-life saga of two British officers who escaped from an Ottoman prison camp during World War I by brainwashing and manipulating their captors.
content: THE CONFIDENCE MEN How Two Prisoners of War Engineered the Most Remarkable Escape in HistoryBy Margalit Fox
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel and Dana Goldstein
title: Disputing Racism’s Reach, Republicans Rattle American Schools
description: In a culture-war brawl that has spilled into the country’s educational system, Republicans at the local, state and national levels are trying to block curriculums that emphasize systemic racism.
content: In Loudoun County, Va., a group of parents led by a former Trump appointee are pushing to recall school board members after the school district called for mandatory teacher training in “systemic oppression and implicit bias.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Phillips-Fein
title: We Are Facing a Turning Point for New York City
description: Coming out of the pandemic, is it possible to build a more equal city?
content: One year after the terrifying first wave of Covid swept the city, the availability of federal aid has helped buoy New York through the pandemic. It’s likely that the city will even see a budget surplus for 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Smith
title: In Compton, a School That Paved the Way for Generations of Black Artists
description: Between 1969 and 1975, the Communicative Arts Academy was a vital hub for a community largely excluded from Los Angeles’s cultural institutions.
content: In Compton, Calif., in the late 1960s and early ’70s, public school students sang “Lift Every Voice and Sing” after the national anthem at the start of classes each day. It was a Black city. Following the Watts Rebellion — the uprisings that took place in August 1965 in the predominantly Black Watts neighborhood, just north of Compton in southern Los Angeles — white residents who hadn’t already left the area were desperate to get out. By the end of that decade, Compton’s population, which had previously been mostly white, was about 70 percent Black. “The difference between Compton in 1959 and in 1969 is almost like night and day,” says Robert Lee Johnson, a local historian. When the city elected Douglas Dollarhide, its first Black mayor, in 1969, he came into office with a majority Black school board and an entirely Black City Council. But keeping the city middle class was an uphill battle. The mass relocation of white-owned businesses led to sweeping job losses and soon Compton, which had formerly been “known for its housing and schools,” Johnson says, couldn’t afford to maintain either, let alone support the arts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Why the Grand Slam Tournaments Risked Playing Hardball With Naomi Osaka
description: Leaders in the game noted that Osaka’s decision to bypass news conferences came as major media organizations had been cutting back on tennis coverage for years, a troubling dynamic for a sport that battles for exposure.
content: PARIS — The message was strong and swift, coming just hours after Naomi Osaka skipped a post-match news conference: If she did not start showing up for questioning, tennis officials would kick her out of the French Open, and perhaps out of Wimbledon, the United States Open and the Australian Open, as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Youmi Kim and Mike Ives
title: Belgium Recalls Ambassador Whose Wife Slapped a Shop Clerk in Seoul
description: The Belgian embassy in South Korea said it would recall its ambassador because he could no longer work in a “serene way” after his wife slapped a shop assistant in Seoul.
content: SEOUL — The shop assistant followed the ambassador’s wife out of a Seoul clothing store, stopped her in the street and checked the label of her jacket to make sure it had not been shoplifted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Katie Glueck
title: N.Y.C. Mayor’s Race Tightens Ahead of Crucial In-Person Debate
description: Democratic hopefuls sharpened attack lines as they tried to draw contrasts on critical issues like policing and the city’s economic recovery.
content: The leading Democratic candidates vying to become New York City’s next mayor veered sharply into attack mode on Tuesday, as they sought to draw distinctions on how they would address critical issues like crime and the city’s economic recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Broadway’s Rebound Advances Again: ‘Pass Over’ Is to Start in August
description: The acclaimed drama by Antoinette Chinonye Nwandu is planning to start performances nearly a month before the big musicals begin.
content: The return of Broadway is gaining steam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: The Covid Vaccine Is Free, but Not Everyone Believes That
description: Concern over unexpected bills was one of the reasons respondents in a U.S. survey gave for hesitation about getting the shot.
content: When Paul Moser considers getting a coronavirus vaccine, he also thinks about his outstanding medical debt: $1,200 from a few urology visits that he has been unable to pay off.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Was Right. Love Can Never Be Compared.’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: “I’m so happy to be here with you,” Ugonna said, looking at me. I was stunned. After months apart during the pandemic, my best college friend and I had finally reunited. Sitting across from each other, eating comforting falafels as the cicadas chirped, Ugonna said it again, even more enthusiastically. I remember how easily I used to express my appreciation to friends at recess or to my mother pushing me in her grocery cart. When did I stop telling people I was so happy to be with them? “I’m so happy to be here with you too,” I said. — Khue Tran
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: With Homicides Rising, Cities Brace for a Violent Summer
description: Homicide rates in large cities were up more than 30 percent on average last year, and up another 24 percent for the beginning of this year, according to criminologists.
content: The upbeat mood at an album release party at El Mula Banquet Hall in Miami-Dade County was shattered when three men in ski masks jumped out of a stolen white Nissan S.U.V. and fired randomly into the crowd early Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Promises Tulsa Massacre Survivors Their Story Will Be ‘Known in Full View’
description: The president, who has made racial equity and justice central themes of his administration, was in Tulsa, Okla., to commemorate a painful part of the country’s history.
content: WASHINGTON — A century after a white mob destroyed a vibrant African American community in Tulsa, Okla., torching hundreds of homes and indiscriminately shooting people in the streets, President Biden told a crowd of survivors and their families that the story of the massacre “will be known in full view.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Glum to Gleeful, Israeli Media React to Possible End of Netanyahu Era
description: In Israel’s newspapers — as fractured as its electorate — the opinions on the possible fall of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu were as emphatic as they were varied.
content: After more than 12 consecutive years at the helm of Israel’s government, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s hold on power may be coming to a close.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gendler
title: 2021 French Open: What to Watch on Wednesday
description: Daniil Medvedev, Stefanos Tsitsipas and Serena Williams feature on the first day of second-round matches.
content: How to watch: 5 a.m. to 6 p.m. Eastern time on Tennis Channel; streaming on Tennis Channel+.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naoise Dolan
title: Kristen Arnett’s Latest Subjects Are the Lesbian Parents of an Autistic-Coded Son
description: In “With Teeth,” two moms struggle to keep their marriage — and their neuroatypical child — alive.
content: WITH TEETH By Kristen Arnett
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Rosen
title: Want Your Nails Done? Let a Robot Do It.
description: Start-ups are using technology to take a robotic approach to manicures, offering a simple way to provide foolproof nail polish.
content: This article is part of our new series, Currents, which examines how rapid advances in technology are transforming our lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: With most adults vaccinated and case numbers low, Israel removes many restrictions.
description: About 81 percent of Israel’s adult population has been fully vaccinated. People must still wear masks in closed, public spaces.
content: With new coronavirus cases dropping to below 20 a day, Israel on Tuesday retired its Green Pass system and will now allow equal access to restaurants, sports events, cultural activities and the like to vaccinated and unvaccinated citizens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: OPEC Plus agrees to add production as oil prices climb.
description: The member states of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and allied producers like Russia confirmed a plan to increase output in June and July, reflecting growing demand for petroleum.
content: It did not take long. With oil futures rising to levels not seen since 2018, officials from the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and allied producers like Russia met on Tuesday and decided to stick with a plan to gradually ease production curbs agreed to in April.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronique Greenwood
title: Magic Tricks May Fool You, but These Birds Can See Through Them
description: A small experiment using sleights of hand and illusions offers insights into how birds and people perceive the world.
content: The coin is in the illusionist’s left hand, now it’s in the right — or is it? Sleight of hand tricks are old standbys for magicians, street performers and people who’ve had a little too much to drink at parties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ini Archibong
title: Ini Archibong: What We Believe About Storytelling
description: In the rarefied world of art and luxury design, our stories help us negotiate a complex dynamic between personal beliefs and public expectations.
content: This personal reflection is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What do we believe? You can read more essays by visiting The Big Ideas series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Biden Assigns Harris Another Difficult Role: Protecting Voting Rights
description: The vice president has added another, and a politically thorny, problem to her growing portfolio.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden said on Tuesday that he had directed Vice President Kamala Harris to lead Democrats in a sweeping legislative effort to protect voting rights, an issue that is critical to his legacy but one that faces increasingly daunting odds in a divided Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Parul Sehgal
title: A Lucid, Literary Illustration of the Complex, Beautiful Work of Memory
description: In “A Sense of Self,” the psychiatrist Veronica O’Keane flashes narrative skill in exploring the science and mystery of memory.
content: The babies had been switched, of that she was sure. Would her own baby smell like this — like rot? Impostor. She guarded the truth quietly: Her real baby actually lay beneath a small, tilted headstone, in the graveyard near her home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Stockton and Lucy King
title: There’s a Sexual Assault Crisis in the Military. Congress Can Stop It.
description: Troops are more likely to be sexually assaulted by a fellow service member than shot by an enemy in war.
content: Thousands of service members in the United States military report being sexually assaulted every year, but only a small fraction of those cases end in a conviction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Barbecue Sauces Designed for Vegetables
description: The vegan barbecue chef Kerry Fitzmaurice now sells barbecue and hot sauces with grilled vegetables in mind.
content: With her plans for a vegan barbecue restaurant in Greenwich Village on hold since last year, Kerry Fitzmaurice pivoted and put her expertise in a bottle, introducing Pure Grit BBQ: The BBQ Kit, designed specifically for vegetables and plant-based proteins instead of the usual meats. It’s a mild, vinegar-based sauce, with a tomato and pepper component designed, as she puts it, so “it doesn’t overpower vegetables.” You can also use it as a salad dressing with sturdy ingredients like kale. And if you’d like more fire, there is a hot sauce, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Alpert
title: Americans Don’t Want to Return to Lousy Low Wage Jobs
description: But it's helping people finally be picky about turning down lousy jobs.
content: The hopes for a booming pandemic recovery — growth led by jobs gains in the millions every month — were dealt a blow in recent weeks by a disappointing April jobs report. Perhaps we will see better when results for May are released this week, on Friday. But, for weeks, many in Democratic policy and political circles have been queasy about addressing the connection between federally supplemented unemployment insurance benefits and the slowing pace of re-employment at this stage of the recovery from the pandemic. There is almost certainly a common sense connection: If you were a low-wage worker, why aggressively attempt to go back to work at a lousy, low-paying job, when you can make more money collecting unemployment benefits.
source.name: The New York Times

description: A look at one of the entries that fooled solvers in last week’s puzzles.
content: This article was published in error.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval, David Montgomery and Manny Fernandez
title: ‘Contested, Heated Culture Wars’ Mark Ultraconservative Texas Session
description: This was the session that pushed Texas further to the right, at a time when it seemed least likely to do so — as the state becomes younger, less white and less Republican.
content: AUSTIN, Texas — It was a literal exit strategy: Texas Democrats staged a last-minute walkout on Sunday to kill an elections bill that would have restricted voting statewide. The quorum-breaking move — a decades-old maneuver favored by Democratic lawmakers — worked, in dramatic fashion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Turner
title: ‘Port Authority’ Review: Two Outsiders Searching for a Place
description: A Pittsburgh runaway and a star of a Harlem vogueing ballroom connect in Danielle Lessovitz’s drama.
content: It’s difficult to make the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan look appealing onscreen. It has unforgiving lighting and blunt interior design. In her feature directing debut “Port Authority” (in theaters and on demand), the director Danielle Lessovitz gives the arrivals area diffuse lighting. The on-the-fly camera observes the Pittsburgh runaway Paul (Fionn Whitehead) crumpled in the corner, an outsider. But, though its dialogue aspires to make displacement and the search for belonging primary themes, the film struggles to convey that through its visuals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Biden Recognizes Pride Month, Vowing to Fight for L.G.B.T.Q. Rights
description: The official recognition is a turnabout from the policies of President Donald J. Trump, who refused to acknowledge the celebration.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Tuesday issued a presidential proclamation recognizing June as Pride Month, vowing to fight for full equality for the L.G.B.T.Q. community to be codified into law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth G. Dunn
title: A Black Whiskey Entrepreneur Will Help Bankroll Others Like Her
description: Fawn Weaver, the founder of Uncle Nearest Premium Whiskey, has amassed a $50 million venture capital fund to seed minority-owned spirits businesses.
content: In 2017 Fawn Weaver began bottling Uncle Nearest Premium Whiskey as a passion project to honor Nearest Green, the formerly enslaved distiller who taught Jack Daniel how to make whiskey. Four years later, her bourbon has sold nearly 1.5 million bottles, according to a recent report in The Spirits Business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Janice Y.K. Lee
title: Who Can You Count On? And Other Unanswerable but Alluring Questions.
description: In “One Two Three,” Laurie Frankel takes readers to a small town ravaged by chemicals and into the lives of triplets whose lives are far from normal.
content: ONE TWO THREEBy Laurie Frankel
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: With the Candlestick in the Study
description: Finn Vigeland offers us a refreshing snack of a puzzle.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Wow, has it really been a year and a half since Finn Vigeland appeared in the crossword rotation? Why, yes it has! In September 2019, he was shouting commands at us, but this time he has created a juicy puzzle that will quench your Tuesday thirst.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: 8 Comic Books in Honor of Pride
description: Romance, self-discovery and a celebration of identity: Magic is in the air in these comic books and graphic novels, out now through September.
content: These comic books and graphic novels tell stories that will transport readers to various worlds, from elementary school to outer space. They feature characters discovering themselves, relationship challenges and a new take on a legendary hero. All include characters who are gay, lesbian, bisexual or transgender. Happy Pride!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phoebe Reilly
title: Garbage’s Shirley Manson Thrives on Unapologetic Heroines
description: The musician chats about weeping to Patti Smith, getting goose bumps from Yoko Ono and freeing her mind via Louise Bourgeois as her band releases its seventh album.
content: Back in the ’90s, Shirley Manson never expected Garbage would still be making music together nearly 30 years later, and she suspects no one else did, either. “We’re outliers,” the fiery Scottish frontwoman said, referring to bandmates Butch Vig, Duke Erikson and Steve Marker. “We don’t fit into any hip scene. We’ve always done our own thing. I think that’s really rare.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China’s Concrete Jungles Make Room for Green Space
description: A national push to build urban parks is transforming Chinese cities, as the country tries to improve the quality of daily life.
content: SHANGHAI — Suzhou Creek was little more than an open sewer for decades as its murky waters coursed through the heart of Shanghai. Now, it teems with life along verdant banks that stretch for 26 miles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Return-to-office shots.
content: As businesses prepare to bring employees back to the office in the coming months, their executives have been anxiously debating some thorny questions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport, Henry Fountain and Lisa Friedman
title: Biden Suspends Drilling Leases in Arctic National Wildlife Refuge
description: The decision blocks, for now, oil and gas drilling in one of the largest tracts of undeveloped wilderness in the United States.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Tuesday suspended oil drilling leases in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, unspooling a signature achievement of the Trump presidency and delivering on a promise by President Biden to protect the fragile Alaskan tundra from fossil fuel extraction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marzano-Lesnevich
title: X is the Best Letter in the Alphabet
description: It’s now used to indicate sex and gender beyond the binary. But X has always been powerful.
content: As a bookish child, I loved most of all an anthology of stories that sat high on my parents’ white bookshelves. At night, my siblings and I would gather on my littlest sister’s bed while one of my parents read to us. Once I learned to read, I took to raising myself up on my tiptoes to borrow that book and carrying it to the nubbly lime green couch in the playroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Seven European countries begin issuing a digital Covid certificate for travel.
description: The European Union plans to roll them out to all member states by July 1, and to eventually make them available to travelers from outside the bloc.
content: A digital Covid certificate system intended to ease travel within the European Union became operational in seven countries on Tuesday — ahead of schedule — offering a preview of what could become a standard for post-pandemic global mobility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Traub
title: Ben Rhodes Takes a Gloomy Tour of the World
description: Rhodes’s “After the Fall” surveys the dangers America’s policies have helped create, and how those dangers are coming back to haunt us.
content: AFTER THE FALL
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: Why ‘Kim’s Convenience’ Is ‘Quietly Revolutionary’
description: In not explaining every detail of Korean food culture, the award-winning Canadian sitcom speaks volumes.
content: In the second episode of the television show “Kim’s Convenience,” there’s a moment that has always stuck with Diane Paik.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Anti-Government Activist in Belarus Stabs Himself in Courtroom
description: Before his apparent suicide attempt, Stepan Latypov said he had been tortured and his family threatened, amid President Alexander G. Lukashenko’s efforts to stifle dissent.
content: MOSCOW — An opposition activist in Belarus stabbed himself in the throat with a pen during a court hearing on Tuesday after claiming that investigators had threatened to prosecute his family and neighbors if he did not plead guilty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan-El Padilla Peralta
title: Three New Memoirs Reveal the ‘Vertigo’ of Life in the Diaspora
description: Reflections on the languages of migration, from Claudio Lomnitz, Michelle Zauner and Quiara Alegría Hudes.
content: NUESTRA AMÉRICAMy Family in the Vertigo of Translation By Claudio Lomnitz 445 pp. Other Press. $27.99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: Why a New Mexico House Race Is a Crucial Test of the G.O.P. Focus on Crime
description: In a special election to replace Deb Haaland, Democrats are bolstering their nominee, taking no chances that a law-and-order argument against her will cost them what should be a safe House seat.
content: ALBUQUERQUE — In theory, the special election to fill Interior Secretary Deb Haaland’s seat in the House should not be competitive. President Biden carried the Albuquerque-based district by 23 points last year, and there has not been a close race for Congress here since George W. Bush was president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phoebe Reilly
title: Marina’s Music Was Caught Between Worlds. Now She’s Making Her Own.
description: The musician’s albums reveal an intriguing if uneasy dialogue with her own pop persona. Her fifth LP, “Ancient Dreams in a Modern Land,” is a firm statement of self.
content: LOS ANGELES — Marina Diamandis moved from London to Los Angeles during the pandemic fall, but she has already discovered some of the city’s trendiest literary emissaries. “Eve Babitz didn’t get her due,” she said recently, scanning the shelves at West Hollywood’s Book Soup for the author’s “Slow Days, Fast Company,” a cult favorite of California-set vignettes. “Joan Didion kind of eclipsed her.” With a wry smirk, she added, “There’s only ever room for one woman.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Here’s what happened in markets today.
description: Economic data is improving, but manufacturers are struggling to meet rising demand, which could add to inflationary pressures.
content: Stocks were mostly unchanged on Tuesday as new data showed evidence of a strengthening global economic recovery but included signs that manufacturers are struggling to keep up with demand, which could increase inflationary pressures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Rules on Tribal Police and Immigrants’ Testimony
description: In unanimous decisions, the justices refused to suppress evidence found by a tribal officer and rejected a presumption in favor of immigrants’ credibility.
content: WASHINGTON — In a pair of unanimous decisions, the Supreme Court ruled Tuesday that tribal police officers may sometimes detain and search non-Native Americans on federal highways and that there is no presumption that testimony from immigrants fighting deportation is credible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Brown
title: Something Bothering You? Tell It to Woebot.
description: When your therapist is a bot, you can reach it at 2 a.m. But will it really understand your problems?
content: “I understand that you’re experiencing a relationship problem, is that right?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: Mafia Killer Who Became a Turncoat Is Released From Prison in Italy
description: Giovanni Brusca completed 25 years in prison for murder, including the killings of Giovanni Falcone, an anti-mafia crusader, and a 14-year-old boy he dissolved in acid. He later became an informant.
content: Giovanni Brusca, an Italian mobster turned informer, has been released after serving 25 years in prison for murder and associating with the mafia, rekindling memories of the country’s battle against organized crime in the 1990s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Damour
title: Why Teens Need a Break This Summer
description: The pandemic has been the psychological workout of their lives. The next few months can be a time of recovery.
content: In the more than two decades I’ve spent as a psychologist working with adolescents, I have never seen teenagers so worn down at the end of an academic year as they are right now. Whether classes have been online, in-person or hybrid, young people are dragging themselves to the finish line of a frustrating, depressing and, for some, unbearably isolating year of school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced and Lauren Hirsch
title: When Work Takes a Toll on Mental Health
description: Tennis stars and regular people alike struggle with wellness at work.
content: The tennis star Naomi Osaka withdrew from the French Open yesterday, citing concern for her well-being, one day after officials threatened to expel her for not wanting to participate in news conferences. To us, this raises a number of questions, including: What’s to be done when one’s job includes tasks that pose risks to mental health?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheila Glaser
title: In César Aira’s World, Life Is a Series of Chance Encounters
description: “The Divorce,” Aira’s newly translated novel, presents as many riddles as answers.
content: THE DIVORCEBy César AiraTranslated by Chris Andrews
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Porter
title: A Rural-Urban Broadband Divide, but Not the One You Think Of
description: Many more people in cities lack broadband access than in rural areas, but lawmakers are primarily focused on extending high-speed access to remote areas.
content: Whom should the government help get superfast internet access?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Shops Along Ponte Vecchio Longingly Wait for Tourists
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 1, 2021.
content: “This summer, we won’t have the numbers we had in 2019, but we’ll have good-quality people. People who really love Italy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: E.E.O.C. Says Companies Can Mandate Vaccines, but Few Push Ahead
description: The agency reminded employers to consider the fact that access to the vaccine was not yet equitably distributed.
content: The agency that enforces workplace discrimination laws has said — twice — that companies can make their employees who are returning to the job get vaccinated against Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Brush Up on Your Canning Skills
description: A series of webinars from Penn State Extension covers the basics of food preservation.
content: The growing season has barely gotten underway, but it’s not too soon to extend the life of the harvest. Canning, pickling, drying and other methods of food preservation will be covered in a series of webinars by Penn State Extension. They start June 9 with an introduction to drying, followed by pressure canning (June 22), steam canning (June 30) and water bath canning (July 26). These 90-minute recorded sessions will be sent to those who register. An interactive session called “Home Food Preservation: Ask the Experts” will also be held at noon on June 28. Some sessions are free, others have a $5 fee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Cocktail Shaker Made from American Stainless Steel
description: This Boston cocktail shaker, made in the U.S., is the first product from a new barware company, C&D Tools.
content: The classic Boston shaker for cocktails consists of two metal cans, one larger than the other, that fit together so you can vigorously shake and mix the ingredients inside with ice. A new company, C&D Tools, which was started by two American diplomats, Kris Forrest and Rebecca Beardsley, has introduced a shaker made from American stainless steel. The material is very substantial, adding heft to the shaking process for more heavy-duty mixing. “The barware we use in America is not made in America,” Mr. Forrest said. “We hope to change that.” The shaker is costlier than most but it should last a long time. The company, which sells only American-made bar gear, does not sell a strainer for the shaker, but one is in the works.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: The World Health Organization authorizes the Sinovac vaccine for emergency use.
description: The clearance means that the vaccine could be distributed as part of Covax, the global effort to share shots with hard-hit, undersupplied nations.
content: The World Health Organization has cleared a Covid-19 vaccine made by the Chinese pharmaceutical company Sinovac for emergency use, opening the way for it to be included in Covax, the sputtering worldwide initiative that low-income countries rely on for the vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cameron Walker
title: Seasonal Affective Disorder Isn’t Just for Winter
description: Feeling blue even though everyone seems to be basking in perfect summer weather? There might be a good reason for that.
content: This is what happens to the Earth during summer: Tilted about 23.5 degrees, it arrives at a place in its orbit where the Northern Hemisphere leans toward the sun. This is what happens in Wisconsin during summer: People go outside, maybe to picnics or parks, to barbecues, on day trips, on summer vacation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: June Vocabulary Challenge
description: How many of our recent Words of the Day can you use correctly in a 50-word story? Send us yours by June 15. And check out the winners of our May challenge!
content: Note: This is our final Vocabulary Challenge of the 2020-21 school year. We plan to publish a new calendar of vocabulary activities for the next school year by August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: California’s Monarch Butterflies Are Down 99%. Can This Plant Help?
description: A coalition of conservation groups have partnered with the state to add 30,000 milkweed plants in an attempt to restore the species’ population.
content: Known for their windowpane wing design and bright orange color, Western monarch butterflies add a dash of magic to the California coast, where they spend the winter. Now a coalition of conservation groups, the California Department of Fish and Wildlife, and the environmentalist organization River Partners are working together to extend a lifeline to the monarchs, whose population has been dwindling drastically.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Editor of JAMA Leaves After Outcry Over Colleague’s Remarks on Racism
description: Dr. Howard Bauchner will step down after another editor suggested “taking racism out of the conversation” on a journal podcast.
content: Following an outcry over comments about racism made by an editor at JAMA, the influential medical journal, the top editor, Dr. Howard Bauchner, will step down from his post effective June 30.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Doherty
title: Michelle Orange Tackles a Writerly Taboo: Her Mother
description: Few subjects may be as resistant to successful literary examination. But in “Pure Flame” the author, assisted by a literature on feminism and motherhood, brings a cleareyed approach to her relationship with her mother, an ambitious businesswoman.
content: PURE FLAMEA Legacy By Michelle Orange
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Western States Face Excessive-Heat Warnings and Advisories
description: Temperatures in the San Joaquin Valley of California hit 108 on Tuesday and areas across Washington could reach the lower 100s, the National Weather Service said.
content: Dangerously hot conditions and triple-digit temperatures are forecast for the Western United States this week, leading to a wave of excessive-heat warnings and heat advisories from Central California and Nevada up to Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edmund Lee
title: ‘SpongeBob’ and ‘Transformers’ Cost U.S. Taxpayers $4 Billion, Study Says
description: A new report details ViacomCBS’s use of a labyrinthine tax shelter to sell rights to its shows and films overseas.
content: Dismissed by critics and devoured by fans, “Transformers: Age of Extinction” was the top box office film in 2014, bringing in $1.1 billion, with more than three-quarters of those dollars coming from overseas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Four Lessons From Your Anxious Brain
description: Pandemic life has saddled us with lots of conflicting emotions. Here’s how to cope with feelings of uncertainty and make a fresh start.
content: Feeling unsettled? Anxious? Overwhelmed? Welcome to the summer of 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Naomi Osaka and the Changing Power Dynamics in Sports
description: With relatively few words, she said a lot as she bowed out of the French Open on her terms, reflecting the growing empowerment of athletes.
content: Thirteen sentences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: As Venice Floods, a Lush, Malice-Infused Mystery Unfolds
description: In “Palace of the Drowned,” Christine Mangan explores the uneasy relationship between two women.
content: PALACE OF THE DROWNEDBy Christine Mangan
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: The Fantasy of a Cotswolds Country Home Meets Reality in Westchester
description: The plan was to do a quick cosmetic update. Then a couple found out the plumbing, electrical and septic systems were shot. And the house was sinking.
content: Like so many renovation projects, the transformation of Keren and Thomas Richter’s 1850s farmhouse in Pound Ridge, N.Y., involved no shortage of surprises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sima
title: Elephant Trunks: Is There Anything They Can’t Do?
description: A new study highlights the impressive biomechanics and suction power of an elephant’s most defining appendage.
content: An elephant’s trunk is a marvel of biology. Devoid of any joints or bone, the trunk is an appendage made of pure muscle that is capable of both uprooting trees and gingerly plucking individual leaves and also boasts a sense of smell more powerful than a bomb-sniffing dog’s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Hinga Klein
title: Some U.S. states have higher vaccination rates inside prisons than outside.
description: Many states are slow to vaccinate incarcerated people despite the high risk of outbreaks in prisons and jails. But some are doing better with inmates than with the wider public.
content: While most of the United States’ prison systems have struggled to vaccinate inmates, those in California and some other states have outperformed vaccination rates among the general public. And experts say their success may offer clues about how to persuade skeptical people outside correctional facilities to get vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn
title: How Do Animals Safely Cross a Highway? Take a Look.
description: There are few things Americans can agree on these days. Wildlife crossings, it seems, are one of them.
content: There are few things Americans can agree on these days. Wildlife crossings, it seems, are one of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak and Alicia Parlapiano
title: What the Public Thinks About Major Supreme Court Cases This Term
description: Closely divided opinions on health care, voting, religion and gay rights cases.
content: Closely divided opinions on health care, voting, religion and gay rights cases.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New Mexico Special Election Results: First Congressional District
description: See full results and maps from the New Mexico special election.
content: See full results and maps from the New Mexico special election.

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Opinion: Takeaways from My Obama Interview
description: For my latest episode, I spoke with former President Barack Obama about how he believes America has changed since his time in office.
content: For my latest episode, I spoke with former President Barack Obama about how he believes America has changed since his time in office.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Cotswolds Country House, in Pound Ridge, N.Y.

content: The plan was to do a quick cosmetic update. Then they found out the plumbing, electrical and septic systems were shot. And the house was sinking.

title: Putting the Beefy Swagger in Korean Barbecue
description: An updated version of a traditional restaurant style, Yoon Haeundae Galbi excels at beef, especially short rib.
content: An updated version of a traditional restaurant style, Yoon Haeundae Galbi excels at beef, especially short rib.

author: By The Associated Press
title: Watch Live: Biden Commemorates 100th Anniversary of Tulsa Race Massacre
description: President Biden travels to Tulsa, Okla., on Tuesday to commemorate the 1921 massacre in Greenwood, the city’s African American community that was destroyed by a white mob 100 years ago.
content: President Biden travels to Tulsa, Okla., on Tuesday to commemorate the 1921 massacre in Greenwood, the city’s African American community that was destroyed by a white mob 100 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joni Ernst, Don Christensen and Mei-Ling Jerez
title: There’s a Sexual Assault Crisis in the Military. Congress Can Stop It.
description: Service members are more likely to be sexually assaulted by a fellow soldier than shot by an enemy at war. The crisis persists because of an archaic set of rules that gives commanders control over whether perpetrators are prosecuted. In this video guest essay, a Republican senator, a former military prosecutor and a survivor call for sexual assault cases to be handled by independent, specialized prosecutors.
content: Service members are more likely to be sexually assaulted by a fellow soldier than shot by an enemy at war. The crisis persists because of an archaic set of rules that gives commanders control over whether perpetrators are prosecuted. In this video guest essay, a Republican senator, a former military prosecutor and a survivor call for sexual assault cases to be handled by independent, specialized prosecutors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Biden Memorializes Victims of the Tulsa Race Massacre
description: President Biden marked the anniversary of the Tulsa race massacre a century after a white mob destroyed the Black community of Greenwood, torching hundreds of buildings and shooting people in the streets.
content: President Biden marked the anniversary of the Tulsa race massacre a century after a white mob destroyed the Black community of Greenwood, torching hundreds of buildings and shooting people in the streets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Texas House Of Representatives
title: Texas Democrats Block Restrictive Voting Rights Bill
description: A large group of Democrats walked out of the House chamber in Austin late Sunday, preventing a quorum in order to block the final vote on a restrictive voting bill that would cut back polling hours and reduce access to mail-in voting.
content: A large group of Democrats walked out of the House chamber in Austin late Sunday, preventing a quorum in order to block the final vote on a restrictive voting bill that would cut back polling hours and reduce access to mail-in voting.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Republican Efforts to Restrict Voting, in Texas and Beyond
description: Readers decry a Texas bill that they view as an undemocratic attempt to suppress the vote. Also: Naomi Osaka; the At Home section; kids with autism.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 1, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, June 1, 2021.
content: A picture with an article on May 28 about children killed in the Israel-Hamas war was published in error. The child in the photograph was not Rahaf al-Masri, who was among those killed. The photograph has been replaced online with a photograph supplied by Rahaf’s family.
source.name: The New York Times
